[[1]](#cite_note-1) [[5]](#cite_note-5) Narconon operates several dozen residential centers worldwide, chiefly in the U.S. and western Europe. The organization was formed in 1966 by Scientologist William Benitez with Hubbard's help, and was incorporated in 1970. [[6]](#cite_note-reitman-257-6) While both Scientology and Narconon state that Narconon is a secular program independent of the church's religious doctrines, [[7]](#cite_note-thestar.com-7) and that it provides legitimate drug education and rehabilitation, [[8]](#cite_note-8) [[9]](#cite_note-cs.cmu.edu-9) the organization has been described by many government reports and former patients as a [Scientology front group](/wiki/Scientology_front_groups). [[10]](#cite_note-westlake_post_1-10) [[11]](#cite_note-sunday_times_1-11) [[12]](#cite_note-itself_to_blame-12) [[13]](#cite_note-greed_and_power-13) [[14]](#cite_note-germans-14) Hubbard's writings, underlie the program, assert that drugs and their metabolites are stored in the body's [fatty tissue](/wiki/Fatty_tissue), causing the addict's cravings when partially released later on, and can be flushed out through a regimen known as [Purification Rundown](/wiki/Purification_Rundown), which involves exercise, sauna and intake of high doses of vitamins. [[15]](#cite_note-prison_system-15) This hypothesis is contradicted by experimental evidence, and is not medically accepted. [[6]](#cite_note-reitman-257-6) [[16]](#cite_note-CHKRC-16) [[17]](#cite_note-salon1-17) [[18]](#cite_note-18) [[19]](#cite_note-norkc-19) [[20]](#cite_note-20) There are no independently recognized studies that confirm the efficacy of the Narconon program. [[19]](#cite_note-norkc-19) The program has garnered considerable controversy as a result of its origins in Scientology [[10]](#cite_note-westlake_post_1-10) [[21]](#cite_note-four_basic-21) [[22]](#cite_note-give_awards-22) and its methods. Its drug rehabilitation treatment has been described as "medically while academic and medical experts have dismissed its educational program as containing "factual errors in basic concepts such as physical and mental effects, addiction and even spelling". [[28]](#cite_note-SF_Chronicle-28) Narconon's facilities have been the location of several deaths, some of which have been linked to a lack of trained medical personnel on site. History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=1)] Origins[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=2)] Narconon, with the Scientology program, is another example of the workability of Dianetics and Scientology.— Scientology and It's (sic) Applications [[29]] Narconon was established 19 February 1966 as a [drug rehabilitation](/wiki/Drug_rehabilitation) program based on the book [Scientology: The Fundamentals of Thought](/wiki/Bibliography_of_Scientology#Basic_Books) by [L. Ron Hubbard](/wiki/L._Ron_Hubbard), the creator of [Scientology](/wiki/Scientology), and was first delivered to drug abusers in the [Arizona prison system](/wiki/List_of_Arizona_state_prisons). The name "Narconon" originally referred not to an organization but to the program. Narconon's creator was William C. Benitez, a former [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona) prison inmate who had served time for narcotics offenses. [[30]](#cite_note-30) His work was supported by Hubbard, and in 1970 Hubbard sponsored the incorporation of Narconon as an organization. [[31]](#cite_note-About_Hubbard-31) The organization was co-founded by Benitez and two Scientologists, [Henning Heldt](/wiki/Henning_Heldt) and Arthur Maren. Even before Narconon became established, Scientology and [Dianetics](/wiki/Dianetics) were promoted as providing a cure for [drug addiction](/wiki/Drug_addiction). In 1970, the Rev. John W. Elliot, senior minister of the [Church of Scientology](/wiki/Church_of_Scientology) and chairman of its Drug Abuse Prevention team, announced that "Dianetic Counseling" had "completely cured 30 out of 30 people" who came to Scientology for help. Rev. Elliott also reported that Dianetics could cure [hay fever](/wiki/Hay_fever), [asthma](/wiki/Asthma) and [arthritis](/wiki/Arthritis). [[32]](#cite_note-drolet1-32) In the early days of Narconon, no distinction was made between Scientology's "religious" and "secular" branches; Narconon was considered by Scientologists to be an example of Scientology in action. "Narconon, with the Scientology program, is another example of the workability of Dianetics and Scientology", said an adherent in 1970. "The program has been expanded and is used in all Scientology churches and missions". [[29]](#cite_note-mercer_island-29) The Narconon website reports that the keynote of Narconon is that the "...individual is responsible for his own condition and that anyone can improve his condition if he is given a workable way to do so... man is basically good and it is pain, suffering, and loss that lead him astray". It positions the program as an approach to rehabilitation without recourse to alternative drugs. This early program did not, however, deal directly with [withdrawal](/wiki/Drug_withdrawal) symptoms. In 1973, the Narconon program adopted procedures to include drug-free withdrawal. [[31]](#cite_note-About_Hubbard-31) 21st century[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=3)] A number of Scientologist celebrities have publicly attested that Narconon was helpful in their own lives. Musician [Nicky Hopkins](/wiki/Nicky_Hopkins) and actress [Kirstie Alley](/wiki/Kirstie_Alley) have credited Narconon for their recovery from addiction to drugs and alcohol. [[33]](#cite_note-33) Alley subsequently became a public spokesperson for Narconon. Elsewhere, the [New York Rescue Workers Detoxification Project](/wiki/New_York_Rescue_Workers_Detoxification_Project) has used Hubbard's sauna detoxification regimen in an effort to improve the health of rescue workers exposed to toxic substances from [9/11](/wiki/9/11), although the results are disputed. [[34]](#cite_note-Hubbard's_Drug_Rehabilitation_Program-34) [[35]](#cite_note-gilmore2004-35) [[36]](#cite_note-crouch-36) Toxicologist Dr Ronald E. Gots described the Narconon / [Purification Rundown](/wiki/Purification_Rundown) program in a 1987 report on its use by [California](/wiki/California) firefighters: The treatment in California preyed upon the fears of concerned workers, but served no rational medical function. ... Moreover, the program itself, developed not by physicians or scientists, but by the founder of the Church of Scientology, has no recognized value in the established medical and scientific community. It is [quackery]. [[37]] In 2004 and 2005, [WISE](/wiki/World_Institute_of_Scientology_Enterprises) at Work magazine and International Scientology News each published articles clarifying the relationship between Narconon and Scientology; each placed Narconon in Scientology's "Division 6B", with responsibility for introducing the public to Scientology services. [[38]](#cite_note-ISN1-38) [[39]](#cite_note-wise_at_work1-39) By the end of 2005, according to the [International Association of Scientologists](/wiki/International_Association_of_Scientologists) (IAS), Narconon was operating 183 rehabilitation centers around the world. New centers opened that year included in [Hastings](/wiki/Hastings), [East Sussex](/wiki/East_Sussex), [[40]](#cite_note-40) Narconon President Clark Carr asserted that drug prevention lectures "have been given to over 2 million children and adults over several decades... and are currently being delivered across the United States, all [New England](/wiki/New_England) States, [Washington D.C.](/wiki/Washington_D.C.), California, [Nevada](/wiki/Nevada), [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii) and possibly in response to an inquiry from The Humanist. [[41]](#cite_note-humanist-41) On 17 July 2006, the Narconon center in [Trois-Rivières](/wiki/Trois-Rivi%C3%A8res), [Canada](/wiki/Canada), started was a [wiki](/wiki/Wiki) purported to contain drug information. The domain name of Narcodex.ca was owned by [ABLE Canada](/wiki/Association_for_Better_Living_and_Education), a Scientology subsidiary. The funding for the website came entirely from Narconon Trois-Rivières, which also controlled the content on the site. [[44]](#cite_note-44) The center was closed by the local health authorities in 2012. [[45]](#cite_note-45) In July 2013, Narconon proposed to acquire the 150 acre [Hockley](/wiki/Hockley,_Ontario), [Ontario](/wiki/Ontario), estate of [Donald Blenkarn](/wiki/Donald_Blenkarn), who had died the previous year. Narconon planned to convert the estate into a rehabilitation center for alcohol and other drug use, but drew widespread opposition from residents who were opposed to the presence of a rehab center, and to the presence of Narconon and Scientology specifically. [[46]](#cite_note-hockleyproposal-46) The Blenkarn family ultimately chose to sell to an unidentified person within the community for below the asking price, and rejected a counter-offer from Narconon. [[47]](#cite_note-47) In January 2014, Narconon instituted a Hubbard-based detoxification program in [Annapolis](/wiki/Annapolis), [Maryland](/wiki/Maryland), to treat veterans suffering from war-related conditions. The treatments were funded by the [Department of Defense](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense) through a September 2010 grant for $633,677 given to [University of Albany](/wiki/University_of_Albany), where David O. Carpenter serves as the director of the school's Institute for Health and the Environment and is the program's chief investigator. As of December 2014, seven [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War) veterans completed the program. It was administered on a seven-day-per-week schedule, with the regimen being completed in 33 days. The program's purpose was to discover whether Hubbard's program has a scientific basis for therapy and whether it was effective in reducing symptoms and improving the functional status of veterans whose physical pain and anxiety improved upon completion of the program. Carpenter affirmed that the program was effective in his own treatment. [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-49) [[50]](#cite_note-army-50) Narconon and Scientology[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=4)] Narconon's affiliation with the Church of Scientology has made the program a focus of controversy. [[52]](#cite_note-tulsa2003-52) The organization has never denied that many of its administrators are committed Scientologists or that its methods are based on the teachings of L. Ron Hubbard. In its early days, Narconon used unaltered Scientology materials in its courses, and Scientology executives ran the organization; founders Heldt and Maren were high-ranking members of the public-relations department known as the [Guardian's Office](/wiki/Guardian%27s_Office) (GO). [[55]](#cite_note-55) In April 1970, Scientology spokesman Max Prudente described Narconon as "based solely on the philosophy and tenets of Scientology", [[10]](#cite_note-westlake_post_1-10) claiming an 85% success rate. However, as Narconon promoted its drug treatment services to a variety of governmental jurisdictions within the U.S., the organization repeatedly found itself at the center of controversy when its ties to Scientology were raised by journalists or politicians. [[56]](#cite_note-56) [[57]](#cite_note-57) [[52]](#cite_note-tulsa2003-52) Such ties raised questions about the constitutional appropriateness of governmental bodies sponsoring a religiously affiliated organization (see [Lemon v. Kurtzman](/wiki/Lemon_v._Kurtzman)).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] These problems were further intensified by claims that the program was medically unsound and served as a fundraising and recruitment program for Scientology. [[58]](#cite_note-Experts_challenge-58) [[59]](#cite_note-59) By the late 1970s, Scientology was keen to disavow its connection with Narconon. When the [FBI](/wiki/FBI) [raided Scientology offices on 8 July 1977](/wiki/Operation_Snow_White#Aftermath_and_trial), papers seized revealed that Scientologists were instructed to refer to Narconon and other " [front groups](/wiki/Front_organization#Scientology)" using [code names](/wiki/Code_names): Codes should be used for the names of front groups that we do not want connected with the [C of S]and for anything that gives specific and actual evidence that the C of S is in legal control of B6 groups [of which Narconon was one]. [[51]] In 1994, John Wood, the head of Narconon UK, denied any connection between Narconon and Scientology, saying, "I know beyond doubt that Narconon does not recruit for nor promote the Church of Scientology", despite the final stage in Narconon's process for patients at that time being "Route to nearest Org (Scientology organisation) for further services", [[60]](#cite_note-60) but by 2001 Scientology spokesman Graeme Wilson was describing Narconon as Scientology's "affiliate charity". [[61]](#cite_note-61) A March two Scientology-linked groups, Narconon and the [World Literacy Crusade](/wiki/World_Literacy_Crusade), used anti-drug and learn-to-read programs to gain access to public schools without disclosing their Scientology ties. [[62]](#cite_note-reaches_into_schools-62) [Heber Jentzsch](/wiki/Heber_Jentzsch), president of the Church of Scientology International, who said in an interview that the Purification Rundown saved his life, [[63]](#cite_note-Scientology_probes-63) confirmed after the Herald report was published that Scientology's Los Angeles law firm had hired private investigators to look into the personal life of Herald reporter Joseph Mallia, who wrote the series. The Herald noted numerous other instances over the years where reporters were harassed with " [noisy investigations](/wiki/Fair_game_(Scientology))" after writing stories exposing Scientology. [[63]](#cite_note-Scientology_probes-63) In [Montreal](/wiki/Montreal), Narconon employees describe themselves as "FSM's", a Scientology abbreviation for Field Staff Member, [[64]](#cite_note-64) while in Georgia a memo released under court order showed Narconon executive director Mary Rieser reporting directly to Scientology's [Office of Special Affairs](/wiki/Office_of_Special_Affairs) (OSA) [[65]](#cite_note-WhistleblowerMemoLinkGeorgiaNarononToScientology-65) as well as to parent organization ABLE. Drug rehabilitation program[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=5)] The treatment ... served no rational medical function. Moreover, the program itself ... has no recognized value in the established medical and scientific community. It is [quackery].— Toxicologist Dr Ronald E. Gots [[25]] Since its establishment, Narconon has faced considerable controversy over the safety and effectiveness of its rehabilitation methods and the organization's links to Scientology. Medical professionals have been sharply critical of Narconon's methods, which rely on theories of drug [metabolism](/wiki/Metabolism) that are not supported by mainstream [toxicology](/wiki/Toxicology).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Narconon teaches that drugs reside in [body fat](/wiki/Body_fat), and remain there indefinitely; [[66]](#cite_note-SLCN-66) and that to recover from drug abuse, addicts can remove the drugs from their fat through saunas and use of vitamins. Experts disagree with this basic understanding of physiology, saying that no significant amount of drugs are stored in fat, and that drugs can't be "sweated out" as Narconon claims. [[66]](#cite_note-SLCN-66) In one 2005 report, experts stated that Narconon's treatment methods "does not reflect accurate, widely accepted medical and scientific evidence." [[66]](#cite_note-SLCN-66) Particular criticism has been directed at the therapy's use of vitamins (including massive doses of [niacin](/wiki/Niacin_(substance))) and extended sauna sessions. David Root, an occupational medicine practitioner and a member of the Narconon Scientific Advisory Board, defended the program's validity. He told the [San Francisco Chronicle](/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle) in 1991 that drugs and other poisons "come out through the skin in the form of sebaceous, or fatty, sweat. The material is frequently visible and drips, or is rubbed off on towels". This apparently explains the need for "daily doses of vitamins, minerals, and oils, including niacin". [[67]](#cite_note-67) Narconon's "New Life Program" consists of two principal stages: detoxification and rehabilitation. The program, adapted from Hubbard's [Purification Rundown](/wiki/Purification_Rundown), consists of six elements: [exercise](/wiki/Exercise), sauna, supplements, sufficient liquids, regular diet with fresh vegetables, and adequate sleep. According to Narconon spokesman John Bitinas, there are more than 200 beds at Narconon Arrowhead, the program's flagship center in [Pittsburg County, Oklahoma](/wiki/Pittsburg_County,_Oklahoma). Asked whether medications are used to help patients going through withdrawal, he said that, "Narconon is drug-free, meaning we do not use substitute drugs as part of our rehabilitation process." All patients are assessed at enrollment to determine whether they are "psychiatrically or medically qualified for the level of care we offer here. If they are found to need a higher level of care then Narconon is qualified to offer at that time, they are referred to a more appropriate facility." If patients require medications to treat physical conditions like [diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes) or infections, those medications are prescribed by the Narconon physician, who is part-time but available on-call on a 24-hour basis, according to Bitinas. [[68]](#cite_note-knopf-68) Each U.S. patient spends an average of three to four months at Narconon, for a fee that ranges from $10,000 to around $30,000. [[69]](#cite_note-69) Overview[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=6)] The Narconon detoxification program is based on Hubbard's theory that "small amounts of drugs [and their [metabolites](/wiki/Metabolite)] stored in fat are released at a later time causing the person to re-experience the drug effect and desire to use again." [[34]](#cite_note-Hubbard's_Drug_Rehabilitation_Program-34) According to Narconon, exercise helps to release toxins from body fat as fat deposits are burned for energy, while concurrently releasing chemicals via sweating, [sebum](/wiki/Sebum) (produced by the skin's sebaceous glands), and regular bowel movements. Narconon is not a medical model. The program rejects the [disease model of addiction](/wiki/Disease_model_of_addiction), and its literature has described the terminology used by that model as being disempowering to patients. [[70]](#cite_note-70) The Narconon program follows the "social education" model of drug rehabilitation. The program is four to six months long and includes a regimen of detoxification that includes "aerobic exercise, dry-sauna sweating, hydration and nutrition supplements; life skills trainings; and personalized plans for after-graduation living." The main premise of the detoxification regimen is that "the activation of drug residuals stored in the body can elicit drug cravings in the former drug user thus tempting relapse. The Narconon detoxification regimen is designed to eliminate drug residues from drug users' bodies and thus reduce the cravings that may be caused by these residues." [[16]](#cite_note-CHKRC-16) Experts from mainstream medicine and toxicology have repeatedly argued that Hubbard's method has no validity: "one may from a pharmacological point of view strongly question the idea of using enforced sweating to expel drugs from the body", said Professor Folke Sjoqvist in a 1996 report for the [Swedish](/wiki/Sweden) government, [[71]](#cite_note-71) while an Oklahoma Board of Mental Health report from 1990 states that, "Although minute quantities of some drugs may be found in sweat the amount represents a small fraction of drug elimination". [[72]](#cite_note-ffact1-72) In a [deposition](/wiki/Deposition_(law)) concerning the [death of Patrick Desmond at Narconon Georgia](#Patrick_Desmond,_Norcross,_Georgia,_United_States_(2008)), expert witness Louis A. Casal was questioned by plaintiff's attorney Jeff Harris: [[73]](#cite_note-73) Harris: And the sauna program, what Narconon contends is that in—it in fact detoxifies your body. True? Casal: True. Harris: But there's no scientific basis that you can point me to to support that contention, is there, sir? Casal: You're correct. Harris: So when Narconon states that the sauna program detoxifies its students, you're not aware, as a medical doctor, of any scientific basis for that contention? Casal: I agree. Harris: The vitamin regimen. You're familiar with the vitamin regimen? Casal: Yes, sir. Harris: What—do you have an opinion about whether or not the vitamin regimen is effective at treating addiction? Casal: I believe that it has very likely no bearing whatsoever on the treatment of addiction. Narconon asserts that [methadone](/wiki/Methadone), [amphetamines](/wiki/Amphetamines), [methamphetamines](/wiki/Methamphetamines), [morphine](/wiki/Morphine), [copper](/wiki/Copper), [mercury](/wiki/Mercury_(element)), and other toxins, some consumed years earlier, leave the body by means of sweating. This contrasts with the view of the body's drug retention taken by mainstream science, which has found that most recreational drugs leave the body within a few days (with the exception of [cannabis](/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)), which in the case of frequent use can remain in the body for up to a month). [[74]](#cite_note-74) Niacin[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=7)] According to Narconon, vitamin and mineral supplements are needed to address nutritional deficiencies and offset nutrient loss due to sweating. Other key elements in the program are the use of [niacin](/wiki/Niacin_(substance)), which Hubbard believed to increase free fatty acid mobilization, and the inclusion of polyunsaturated fats that he thought to increase the excretion rate of some toxin compounds. Together with a proper amount of sleep, this regime is thought by Narconon to mobilize and eliminate long-term stored toxins. [[34]](#cite_note-Hubbard's_Drug_Rehabilitation_Program-34) The risk to patients of taking high-dose niacin is one reason why medical experts assessing the Narconon program have found that it is a danger to patients; the program has been banned in a number of jurisdictions including Quebec and [France](/wiki/France) as a result. [[76]](#cite_note-Latour-76) Because Narconon doctrines dictate that patients undergoing its program exhibit physical symptoms relating to the drugs that are (supposedly) being "sweated out," and because Narconon's staff are not medically qualified or typically qualified in orthodox drug rehabilitation, there is a risk that serious medical symptoms—from niacin [overdose](/wiki/Overdose) or from other causes—may be misinterpreted by Narconon staff as the desirable effects of detoxification: [[72]](#cite_note-ffact1-72) The Narconon Program exposes its patients to the risk of delayed withdrawal phenomena such as [seizures], [delirium]and/or [hallucinations]. ... The Narconon program presents a potential risk to the patients of the Narconon program that delayed withdrawal phenomena such as seizures, delirium or hallucination that are occasionally seen several days after cessation of drugs such as benzodiazepines, may be misinterpreted by Narconon's non-medical staff as the effect of mobilizing the drug from fat during the sauna sweat-out procedure period. There is also a potential risk that the reported re-experience of the abused drugs' effect during the sauna sweat-out program may be the result of misinterpreted symptoms of [hyperthermia]or [electrolyte imbalance]... Training Routines[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=8)] The uses "Training Routines" or "TRs" [[77]](#cite_note-NN-TR-77) originally devised by Hubbard to teach communications skills to Scientologists. In the Narconon variant, these courses claim to be designed to rehabilitate drug abusers. [[77]](#cite_note-NN-TR-77) These routines sometimes include TR 8, [[78]](#cite_note-78) which involves the individual commanding an ashtray to "stand up" and "sit down", and thanking it for doing so, as loudly as they can. [[79]](#cite_note-79) [[80]](#cite_note-80) Former Scientologists say that the purpose of the drill is for the individual to "beam" their "intention" into the ashtray to make it move. [[81]](#cite_note-Reitman_TR8-81) Efficacy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=9)] There is currently no reliable evidence for the effectiveness of Narconon as a primary or secondary drug prevention program.— Norwegian Knowledge Centre for the Health Services [[19]] Narconon typically claims success rates as high as 75% of the graduates of its program remaining drug-free for the rest of their lives, [[82]](#cite_note-82) and has in the past claimed "very close to a 100% success rate". [[83]](#cite_note-83) However, these numbers are highly controversial, and there exist no independent studies that support these claims. [[19]](#cite_note-norkc-19) [[84]](#cite_note-84) Independent researchers have found considerably lower rates of success. At least one website critical of Narconon cites a Swedish research study that gives a rate of 6.6%. [[85]](#cite_note-85) Narconon has reported the same study's findings as being much more favorable, although its representation of the study is greatly simplified. [[86]](#cite_note-86) [[87]](#cite_note-87) The Church of Scientology claims that "the Narconon success rate is not merely the world's highest, it is four times better than international averages", [[88]](#cite_note-88) while a [systematic review](/wiki/Systematic_review) of evidence regarding Narconon's efficacy conducted by the Norwegian Knowledge Centre for the Health Services on behalf of the Norwegian Directorate of Health concluded that: [[19]](#cite_note-norkc-19) Collectively, one quasi-experimental and five non-experimental studies document lack of evidence of the preventive effects of these programs. Thus, there is currently no reliable evidence for the effectiveness of Narconon as a primary or secondary drug prevention program. This is partly due to the insufficient research evidence about Narconon and partly due to the non-experimental nature of the few studies that exist. In April 2014, the town council of [Wyong](/wiki/Wyong), [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales), [Australia](/wiki/Australia) refused permission for Narconon to open a new centre at nearby [Yarramalong](/wiki/Yarramalong,_New_South_Wales), saying that the program's method of treatment was a factor in the decision. [[89]](#cite_note-89) Wyong Mayor Doug Eaton said: [[90]](#cite_note-ABC2May14-90) To be allowed in the area it'd have to be defined as a hospital and there wasn't enough material to demonstrate it could be so defined because my understanding of the rehab process it that it is more of a religious process than it is a medical process.— Church of Scientology drug rehab centre rejected, Australian Broadcasting Corporation Education program[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=10)] Florida[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=11)] In 1999, Scientologists from [Clearwater](/wiki/Clearwater,_Florida), [Florida](/wiki/Florida), tried to get a Narconon drug education program instituted into the [Pinellas County](/wiki/Pinellas_County,_Florida) school district curriculum. After a hearing on the matter, a school district committee refused to allow students to participate in an anti-drug program based on Hubbard's teachings, citing that teaching students about the " [tone scale](/wiki/Emotional_tone_scale)" and other trappings of Scientology was inappropriate for a drug education program for their schools. [[91]](#cite_note-91) California[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=12)] In 2004, Narconon offered an anti-drug program to public schools in California, free of charge. However, a series of articles in the San Francisco Chronicle in June 2004, resulted in California school officials investigating Narconon's claims. The study found that Narconon's program did not reflect medically and scientifically based practices and that it offered students misleading information about drug use and abuse. [[92]](#cite_note-EW-92) As a result of the investigation, on 23 February 2005, the state's superintendent of public instruction, Jack O'Connell, officially recommended that all schools in the state reject the Narconon program. [[93]](#cite_note-93) O'Connell's secretary announced that the school systems in Los Angeles and [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco) had dropped the program. The president of Narconon, Clark Carr, responded that the study presented only limited information about his organization's work, and that those efforts were "accurate and relevant to the current challenges children face with drugs." [[92]](#cite_note-EW-92) A May 2014 investigation by the Chronicle discovered that some California schools were still using the Narconon program, in spite of the 2004 decision. Steve Heilig, one of the experts who evaluated the Narconon education program on behalf of the school district and found it to be scientifically unsound, [[94]](#cite_note-94) urged schools to check the accreditation of drug education programs before allowing them access to students, saying, "One imperative of drug education is that we not deceive students, as once they discover that you are not telling them factual information, they are likely to disbelieve everything you say". [[95]](#cite_note-95) United Kingdom[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Narconon&action=edit§ion=13)] The UK prisons [ombudsman](/wiki/Ombudsman) recommended to prison governors that Narconon rehabilitation programs not be used in prisons although some schools in the UK are using these programs; [The Sunday Times](/wiki/The_Sunday_Times_(UK)) said this was because schools are less aware of Narconon's links to the Scientology. [[96]](#cite_note-96) In September 2012, the 149 [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England) schools in the Diocese of London were warned not to accept offers from Narconon to give lectures to their pupils, following complaints from parents. [[97]](#cite_note-97) In November 2016, Narconon was reported to have given talks on the dangers of drug addiction in two schools in [Camden, London](/wiki/Camden,_London). Elizabeth Kitcatt, Camden School for Girls headteacher, said in a statement that the students found the talk "very useful", while Harry Shapiro, Director of DrugWise, called out the schools for being unaware to the group's ties to Scientology. A Brecknock Primary spokeswoman said: "The school's deputy head was in the room for the whole drug awareness talk and at no point was there any mention of Scientology or any religious connotations. It was marketed as an anti-drug talk and that's exactly what it was". President of Narconon UK Noel Nile claimed that the group was "in the business of saving lives".
